commentBody:
Here is the Tuesday puzzle!


Nice one, Laura.

Breezy puzzle, although I bogged down a bit in the SW corner.  I kept trying to fit sleasiest in even though I knew it was spelt with a Z not an S.  CHEESIEST eventually came to me.  I got BUMPSETSPIKE, but didn‚Äôt get the theme until after I finished the puzzle ‚Äî then I had a good chuckle, which was the cherry on top of a fun solve.

orale is a terrible answer, as clued. could have clued it as the mexican slang word √≥rale. suspect there was some discussion internally to do it that way, but they made the wrong choice. 

side note (i don‚Äôt post here often): if there is an answer that includes an √± (different letter than n) it should be an √± in both directions. doesn‚Äôt apply to this puzzle but i‚Äôve been sitting on that one for a while

I agree, here‚Äôs the Tuesday puzzle. I also felt that it was my kind of puzzle. First: I don‚Äôt compete in sports but have scored a lot of volleyball games in the last 10 years so bump, set, spike was a gimme.
Second: My junior year of high school I was a towns person in a production of Fiddler on the Roof that opened our newly remodeled auditorium to a SRO audience and 14 curtain calls. 30 years later I was cast as Motel the Tailor‚Äôs mother in a community production that due to COVID got shut down. And Finally: my mom got to see Zero Mostel as Tevya on stage! Can I say easiest clue ever for me!
My solve times are getting faster every day this week
Sorry Sam, it‚Äôs up to me to put a meal on the table every evening.. TACO PIE was an inspiration and what I‚Äôm making tomorrow.

Sorry, really didn't much like this one, although it was way, way easier than yesterday's misplaced and excessively tough (though well done and enjoyable) Tuesday.

There were one or two fine clues here (virtue signal is great) but I thought the theme and theme answers were really weak and, more damningly, boring.  :(

Decent puzzle overall. On to better days.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

Only a minute faster than yesterday üòâ I had two typos to fix. As per usual, the last one was in the SE, so it took me almost 5 minutes to track it down. Having just returned from Hawaii, I had KOnA on the brain. It wasn‚Äôt until I reread the clue that I noticed ‚Äúnut‚Äù ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Oy vey! KOLA it is. 

Thank you, Laura, for this lovely SET.
PRATE?? Truly has anyone ever used that word, ever in your life. And don't prate.
Can someone explain the right leaning type clue
Not a bad puzzle, but pales in comparison to Tuesday‚Äôs staggering mountain of amazingness. There are some fun puns here too.
WHOM has fallen into disuse? I‚Äôd say it‚Äôs fallen into misuse.

The volleyball theme triggered me a bit! I am one of the many 70s kids who wasn't athletic, and suffered in PE class for it. But one of two of my shining moments in PE was volleyball, serving the ball [just] over the net three times and watching the other team just stand there, as they were sure every time that I wouldn't make it. And we won by the margin I provided. !!! Never happened again. Thank you for letting me relive my short-lived triumph!

Volleyball players always order room serve-ace.

(These puns are a net positive.)

I claim the prize for being the first to be slower than yesterday.

Too many beans and noodles and I don't see why swatting a fly is sacrificing it

I was a minute slower than my Wednesday average and fifteen minutes slower than yesterday so I must be the target audience they're building these puzzles for. This one felt hard but fair. Proud to say I got HALO right away. The entire middle from west to east gave me a few hiccups but fell into place once I literally deleted that entire section and started over. Sometimes I stare so long at the existing letters that I lose the trees for the forest or vice versa and a clean slate is helpful.

I thought this was super easy‚Ä¶ until it wasn‚Äôt. PRATE? Uh, ok. Stickiest> sweatiest> CHEESIEST‚Ä¶ finally! (A little more knowledge of dark Greek mythology would have helped me there.) ORALE? Hmm. And who knew Darryl from The Office was Michelle Obama‚Äôs brother? (Just kidding. I got that.) 

Moral of the day: Embrace the rickroll! Never give [it] up.

Commenting early means you‚Äôre with the quick folks. ü´§ For me this was a slog. 

Certainly not easier than yesterday which I also took my time over. 

No one PRATEs

Enjoyed it!  And finished in less than half of Tuesday‚Äôs time, even after losing some minutes to flyspecking in order to find and correct BUMPSETSPIcE.  Overall a rather normal Wednesday for me.  I admit that PRATE was a total guess.

Mark
Yep the Tuesday and Wednesday crosswords switched places this week. Smooth solve except the lower left corner; was on track for ~5 minutes.

Why so many complaints about PRATE?  I though it was an easy gimme!
It's a perfectly cromulent word that (according to xwordinfo) has appeared as an answer 32 times in the modern era.

Dad humor is CORN? Surely you meant CORNY?

Also, ORALE, really? Go type that word into Google and tell me how far you have to scroll before you find the archaic pre-13th century definition that was clued here. 

Truly baffling fill on this one.

That has got to be one of the most impenetrable themes for me, ever ü§£. I know nothing about volleyball in Polish, let alone in English.

Still, I solved the puzzle 2 minutes faster than yesterday's "Tuesday" ü§™.

I have considered giving up my current crossword streak and quitting the crossword community forever. I have had one too many struggles here.  But, then I said:






‚ÄúNever gonna give you up,
Never gonna let you down,
Never gonna run around and desert you!
Never gonna make you cry,
Never gonna say goodbye,
Never gonna tell a lie and hurt you!‚Äù

You‚Äôve just been Rickrolled! ü§£ü•≤ü§£ü§£ 

Okay, I‚Äôll never have a STANDUPACT because that may have been the CHEESIEST, CORNiest use of Rick ASTLEY lyrics.

Anyway, today seemed easier than yesterday to me but I got hung up on so many clues I ended up taking quite a long time. I enjoyed the puzzle more, though.

Shout out to LISBOA, whose district is where I live. Still dealing with ‚ÄúType A‚Äù flu, which the home doctor said is rampant throughout the district and the country. Keep that in mind if you‚Äôre traveling here.  It‚Äôs a pretty rough strain.

Adeus!
I suppose with enough patience, anything can be a pasture noise. But that tripped me up.
Interesting to see people say this puzzle is a lot easier than yesterday's. I found yesterday's to be fairly straightforward but today was harder for me than some Fridays.

I was disappointed to learn there was no Earl of TUPPER, only some guy named Earl who invented TUPPERware. We were not a TUPPERware family when I was growing up, so was always somewhat fascinated with the stuff.
We were, however, a Mel Brooks family, and ZERO MOSTEL will always be Max Bialystock to me. 
And it was nice to be reminded of Say Anything, a "teen movie" with a lot more going on, by IONE Skye and the iconic scene featuring Peter Gabriel's In Your Eyes, a nice antidote to being Rick rolled.

Mini Crossword:

Always have a little snigger filling in the answer to 9A as I'd be willing to bet that it's never appeared in a mainstream newspaper crossword over here...
[Virtue signal?] for HALO and [Noneternal flames?] for EXES - excellent!  Nice puzzle overall, which is what I've come to expect from Laura Dershewitz.

Strands Thread.  No spoilers please until after the View All Replies button: 


Strands #311
‚ÄúTime for an upgrade‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµ

An unusual one today.

Well - not an easy one for me. A longer than usual Wednesday workout, but managed to get through it. Will confess that I was not entirely grasping the theme. No big deal. Interesting (and surprising) that all of the theme answers and the reveal were appearing for the first time in any puzzle. Other than the reveal they seem like quite familiar terms. Hmmm... 

Kind of an odd answer history search result today. Wasn't familiar with ORALE, but it seems like a useful piece of fill. Well... it's been an answer in 197 puzzles. Pretty much at least once almost every year from 1943 to 2006. But then... this is it's first appearance since then. Hmmm...  

Oh well. I'm done. 

...

Same mistake in several puzzles:  Iona instead of IONE.

Some ARCANA for this solver:  ORALE, ASTLEY, LISBOA, ANYA.  But not SO BAd that a little xword STAMINA couldn't solve.

Many people seem to have found this much easier than yesterday's puzzle, but it took me 10 minutes longer! 

Both were done in close to my average time for the day (as was Monday's) so the sequence of difficulty has been correct for me so far this week.

I entered several wrong answers on my first pass (8D Frodo, 24A moo, 58A stickiest). Realising this and correcting them held me up for a while, but overall I found it an enjoyable puzzle.

Thought I was going to crash and burn on this one. Volleyball! I saw that played once, in 1973. 
Various cliff-hangers ensued, followed by hairs-breadth escapes. The realisation that I actually knew the name of an actor in a film I'd never seen; that TUPPERware was presumably named after someone; that I'd filled the name of an unknown noodle entirely on the crosses...
Filled the grid... no happy tune. Scrolled through one clue at a time. Wondered if BUMPSEySPIKE might not be as plausible a volleyball thing as it had intially seemed. Hmmm. Maybe I needed *three* words to match the three other clues this one was supposed to "reveal". Minutes go by. Maybe that entirely impenetrable down solution is EAST, rather than EASy? 

Ta-da.

Wowza. 
If anyone is tempted to add
the archived puzzles to your daily solve,

today should be a solid push.

Felt like I was doing a 1997!

IONE
ASTLEY
ORALE
PRATE‚Ä¶

like the good ol‚Äô days!


I‚Äôll take Rick-rollin for $400 Alex- 

Give you up
Let you down 
Run around 
Desert you
Make you cry
Say goodbye
Tell a lie
Hurt you


Question-

What are eight things Rick Astley
is never gonna do?

Happy Wednesday all!

I see there‚Äôs been some PRATE hate in the comments, and I respect it.  To me, though, it‚Äôs a word I use, and a marvelous word that somehow conveys its meaning in its sound.  I love it.






Et tu, emu.

Definitely more straight forward than yesterday, despite knowing nothing about volleyball, TACO PIE or the clerical garb.

Rick ASTLEY. Ugh. I saw his first appearance on Top of the Pops (must watch music show on the Beeb before MTV). He was wearing a business suit two sizes too big bless him; nice chap but not a fan of his popcorn music.

Udon before SOBA. WalkWAY before HALL. No major holdups otherwise.

A challenging vocabulary expanding experience.  Brings to mind the '70's ERA 7UP commercial, "This!, is a KOLA nut . . . " voiced by Geoffrey Holder. 

But I blab, blabber, chatter, clack, gabble, gibber, maunder, palaver, piffle, prattle, tattle, tittle-tattle, twaddle, yammer.  

Nice one and thanks.

Learned BUMP, as in volleyball, today.  That‚Äôs where a player uses their forearms together to direct the ball to the person who creates a plum for the spiker to smash.  Seen it when I‚Äôve watched volleyball on tv, like in the Olympics, but never knew the name for it.

Something I find amazing is that the three theme answers ‚Äì MINOR PROBLEM, STANDUP ACT, and POWER SURGE ‚Äì all very in the language, have never appeared in the Times puzzle before.  The latter two have appeared in other major venues, but this is a world premier for MINOR PROBLEM.

The grid features schwa de vivre, with that sound ending an octet of answers.  It also features words I adore: IDLE HANDS, PRATE, ARROYO, NIGH, SPOILSPORT, ARCANA.  And I like seeing HELIUM floating high in the grid, and even crossing with RISERS.  

Thus, a sweet solve, with some lovely takeaways.  Thank you very much for this, Laura!
Yeah today and Tuesday's should've been switched lol

Hi puzzlers, 
I have a question from the archives. In the puzzle from Thursday, June 22, 1995 by Cathy Millhauser, the clue for 32D is [While] and the answer is ALL. I‚Äôve looked pretty hard and can‚Äôt find a citation anywhere that would justify this clue-answer pairing. I‚Äôd really welcome learning how this makes sense. Probably obvious, but if so, a blind spot for me. Alternatively, is it possible this is a typo* in the original puzzle, or in copying to the archives (and thus also to xwordinfo.com)?

*maybe the clue was originally something like [ ___ the while] ??
An unimpressive slog. Random googled trivia and foreign terms with a D- theme.

And then there was Moldy Earl, the guy who kept a tuna sandwich in his locker so long the high school had to be closed for three days. He was a hero.

(over-reaching?)

We had a volleyball team in grad school and would play other departments and at times a team comprised of our professors.
After a BUMPSETSPIKE I nailed my advisor in the face.... I still graduated.

Cute solve, thank you Laura

Great puzzle, so this is nitpicky, and I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôs been brought up somewhere here but I haven‚Äôt gone through all the comments (Mountain TZ, late to the party): believe an idle ‚Äúmind‚Äù is the devil‚Äôs workshop. Idle hands typically referred to as the devil‚Äôs plaything. All sayings are iterative, so there‚Äôs no hard/fast here, but caught me on the solve. Happy Wednesday!

Not sure how others felt, but Tuesday and Wednesday seemed transposed this week. Solved this one easily, in less than 3/4 the time I needed yesterday. Only the intersection of ORALE and LISBOA gave me pause.

Today's theme seemed oddly parochial, but solid enough and, again, more Tuesday-ish than yesterday's theme.

Some interesting *words* here: MODAL, ARROYO, STAMINA, ARCANA (of which there was certainly some in the grid).

Liked WHOM/WHAM emanating from the shared W. Another pair that nicely illustrates how non-phonetic English is.
As no doubt most everyone has already said....Now, THAT'S a Tuesday puzzle!!!  Perhaps they mixed up today's and yesterday's. Still no water in the city here in Richmond...day 3!!
Not sure I will ever execute a bump set spike, but at least some day when I see the clue ‚ÄúLinked to an Astley video,‚Äù I will know what the 10 letter response is.

Welp, time to make a couple deposits in the crosswordese bank. 

The PRATExEREBUS and ORALExKOLA crossings accounted for a solid ~quarter of my total solve time.

Yes, all of those clues have appeared in plenty of previous NYT crosswords‚Ä¶but none within the last couple years, and I drew a blank on all four of those today.
ORALE is virtually impossible to solve on its own. Since KOnA and KOLA are both nuts that are a source of caffeine, this intersection was a solution killer for me.
This puzzle, like yesterday's, was a fairly easy solve for me, but I've never head of an orale. Still seems like it's got to be misspelled.

Very fast, but the theme set was nice! I was stumped by ORALE crossing with KOLA (I had put an N in), and, prior to that, got quite hung up at PRATE/EREBUS. I think the latter are fair if a touch obscure, but even when I decided to turn to the net to learn something about papal vestments, I wasn't overwhelmed by information on orales.
Fairly easy solve but had to rely on crosses for the ARCANe glue.

Fun puzzle with an effortless fill. I enjoyed the volleyball theme even though I can probably walk under the net without ducking. Will never get a spike at my height!

Sam, your volleyball story almost made me tear up. Good on you! I hope you still have the medal. It was a lovely gesture and well-deserved.

While I was also hung up on papal vestments and Kona beans, I was particularly thrown by MAA. It had to be MEADOW, and it had to be ASTLEY, but cows go MOO and sheep go BAA? I‚Äôve never heard of anything going MAA. Perhaps noises have evolved since my children were small 20 years ago.
Laughed out loud (all by myself) several times!!!

I always swing wildly between utter fury and delight when I learn a new word. 64A didn't hold up my solve, but I sure as heck have never seen it before. MW didn't recognize it, either. It's desk-pounding frustration followed by "I'll NEVER forget THIS word, ever again!"
Does anyone know how ‚ÄúTalk excessively‚Äù is PRATE?
3:00 over my average, but I enjoyed the challenge for a Wednesday!

This was a breeze until I got to the SE corner where I had to know both a caffeine-source nut (not spelt COLA) and a papal vestment.  I happened to guess correctly, BUT when I looked it up post-solve, the very definition stated that the garb is no longer used.  

Similarly, 10A claims that WHOM is "falling into disuse."  I can say it seems no longer to be taught, along with proper use of ME and I.  One day (years back) our son tossed off the statement tht he hadn't understood when to use WHOM until he studied German.  That's sad--ignorance being perpetrated in educational settings and modeled in daily fare such as advertisements and even news reports.  

Okay, that should take care of today's rant....

I loved volleyball and soccer when we learned those games in PE!  I was encouraged to go out for 'track and field' based on my high-jump skills.  My mother protested that I would be  "getting all sweaty" and nixed it.  Then when I wanted to learn to play the clarinet, my HS schedule forced a choice between Band and PE, so....   (Apparenty it did not occur to Mom that the Marching Band got pretty sweaty out there practicing on the football field...)

Got pretty far down ole Memory Lane today...Merciful heavens!  All y'all stay warm and safe.
Some annoying crosses for a mid weeks puzzle. ZERO MOSTEL/PRATE/EREBUS I just got lucky with. LISBOA/ORALE was maybe a little easier to guess.

BUMP, SET, and SPIKE unfortunately fit nicely at the end of each of the across theme answers. And that threw me for quite a while since I was convinced they ended with it. 

I had BILBO and BUMP in the top middle and couldn‚Äôt figure out what it could possibly be.
I learnt "KOLA nut" from this 7Up commercial. Lonnnnnng time ago! https://youtube.com/watch?v=AXmc7DG4uu8
Wow!  Heloise and Abelard!  Talk about ARCANA.

Word on the hill is that these days Bilbo's having his mail forwarded to Rivendell. Strike that--Tol Eress√´a. (Par avion, c/o Thorondor) Unlike everyone else today, my cheesy 80's earworm--perhaps the cheesiest--is: https://youtube.com/watch?v=pIgZ7gMze7A (I do the jitterbug.)
Somehow, it never occurred to me that there was an eponymous Mr TUPPER, but there he is. (And I'll take any opportunity to use "eponymous" in a sentence.)

Cute puzzle, with lots of smooth fill countered by some very chewy spots! Kind of like when there's a nice rally going on in volleyball -- neither side getting a clincher, so the ball just sails back and forth... until WHAM! A SPIKE slams the point to its conclusion. Or worse, a mis-aimed punch hurtles into the net and ricochets back when there's no more hits to be had... 

In the "interesting coincidence" arena, I couldn't help but notice the placement of Z as the penultimate letter in the 1A answer two days in a row-! Both for names of men better recognized a few decades ago... And both associated with music, but I'll confess neither style of which I could ever get into! At least the names came easily to me.  :)
"Non eternal flames?" Luv it!!!
Not sure I‚Äôve ever seen MAA before, but I like it better than BAA. Also EXES out of ‚Äúnon-eternal flames?‚Äù made me smile. Enjoyed it!

Little quip, but shouldn‚Äôt ‚Äúloops in, in a way‚Äù have some indication that the answer is an abbreviation or acronym? Clues usually follow very strict rules that if the answer is not a complete word that there needs to be some indication of such in the clue.  E.g. ‚Äúloops in, in a way, for short‚Äù
I'm with Deb on 27A.  I have eaten a lot of great Mexican food in my life. But I have never even heard of taco pie.  Yes, Deb, please make it go away.
I am impressed that a woman as young as Sam seems to be can make an appropriate reference to The Twilight Zone. Well done.

Re today's Mini - This is just a very weird coincidence:  I went to my bank yesterday and noticed that there was a small metal sign by the handle of the large, heavy front door that read "Pull". Going out, I saw that there was a similar metal sign on the reverse side of the door that said "Push" and I immediately thought of this Far Side cartoon. I'm always reminded of this, with a chuckle, every time I see someone who's supposed to be oh-so-smart do something oh-so-dumb. (Yup. And especially me. . .)

Who, What, When, Where, Why. (59D)
I've not heard of the five W's in decades, yet my brain immediately popped them up. Crazy.

Thanks, Laura, fun puzzle.

Lewis is wearing off on me, I noticed the puzzle pairs of WHOM and WHAM, MOS and MAS.

This is my first time commenting on this column (my 2025 resolution is to keep a gold streak all year, so it hopefully won‚Äôt be my last!) but I feel like 61D is a bit misleading - BOTOX doesn‚Äôt remove wrinkles, just prevent them.

Loved this puzzle though! I feel like I‚Äôll never run out of new things to learn LOL

Oh I made some bone headed mistakes in this one last night, and I couldn't find them  when I went to finish up today, and my head is pounding and I had to get to a meeting, so, quite unlike Rick ASTLEY, I gave up on my puzzle, I let my puzzle down. I told my puzzle goodbye and deserted it.... err, hit check puzzle. I don't care about streaks, so no big deal. Nothing at all wrong with the puzzle. This is all me and my difficulty muddling through life when my head feels like it's exploding and the light has become my sworn enemy.

Anyhow, I put in a couple of silly mistakes last night, mostly, I inexplicably had gameSETSPIKE, which messed up a few other things obviously, and also I had KOnA and didn't know ORALE. Sure, SPEAn might be a warriors weapon, ARYA could be AnYA....  ETCETERA. Or was that one yesterday?  I could have figured it all out but I would have needed a POWERSURGE.

Also here to speak up for TACO PIE. No one would claim that it's fine or authentic Mexican food, of course, but it's a fun, easy, and tasty comfort casserole that many people enjoy. There's only two of us, so I tend to just make tacos but I would never turn down a nicely made taco pie casserole.

I agree that ORALE is obscure but the crosses made it easy. When I googled it by itself to check, the Spanish expression came up, but  orale + pope made AI come up with a correct  answer AND a picture.  "What a fabulous frock!", as two of the gay men in our church (channeling the Fab Five) once said to the minister when he showed up in a colorful robe.

In 1921, in a discussion of "drift," the linguist Edward Sapir wrote:
"It is safe to prophesy that within a couple hundred years from to-day not even the most learned jurist will be saying, "Whom did you see?" By that time the "whom" will be as delightfully archaic as the Elizabethan "his" for "its." No logical or historical argument will avail to save this hapless "whom."

His argument is that among the few English pronouns marked in the objective case--"me," "her," "him," "us," and "them"--"whom" is an outlier, and destined for extinction.
Dig, set, spike was the terminology I learned back in high school. Alas.

Two more thoughts, I really loved noneternal flames for EXES at 57D! That was EXcellent!

I don't usually do the mini but as I was trying to back out of the comment section here today, somehow I clicked it open in the first clue at 1A was about my beloved Far Side, so I just had to do it. That was awesome! One of my favorite clues ever possibly!

What do we know about H√©lo√Øse and Peter Ab√©lard?

1) that their correspondences have been preserved. They're not as prurient as all that.
2) that, in a 19th c. publicity stunt, (probably-not-really-)their remains were transferred to P√©re Lachaise cemetery in Paris.
3) that it requires three diacritics to correctly write their names.
4) that Alexander Pope's poem "Eloisa to Abelard" is the source of the line "Eternal sunshine of the spotless mind," the title of one of my favorite-- and IMHO, one of the most romantic ever--movies.

Sadly, I know nothing about volleyball, even less about TACO PIE. Thank goodness for crossers in a crossword.
Re: language change. Quite recently, British English started using "change up" and "switch up" when before there was no "up". Is this from the US? Then there's "drop" as in "This new shampoo has just dropped" instead of maybe 'arrived'. Is that from you too?
 Just interested.

When I was a little girl, we lived around the corner from Seton Hall College. Chuck Connors played basketball there. My High School friend, Lee Sager, played in the Essex County Tournament, and then at West Point.

Every item of clothing put on for worship in liturgical religions has a name, a meaning, a status, and a specific prayer attached to its donning.

Some belong to particular offices. Alb is nearly always wrongly clued as ‚Äúpriestly garment‚Äù here in NYT puzzles, since wearing the simple white garment is the privilege of any baptized person serving in the liturgy. Orale is correctly clued as ‚Äúpapal vestment‚Äù because only popes wear the capelet with horizontal stripes called orale (accent on the second syllable; the Mexican interjection is √≥rale, accent on the first).

As I was trained in a very serious corps of altar boys/servers, in a conservative parish of a conservative diocese, I had to memorize and recite the vestment prayers proper to each of the many items worn by myself and the clergy I assisted in vesting. In Latin.

Before any vestiture could be done, there was a ritual washing of hands with its own prayer (Da Domine virtutem manibus meis‚Ä¶) which remains a fixed element for me 50 years later.

The names and prayers are different from faith to faith, sect to sect, place to place, but what Catholics, Anglicans, Jews, Muslims etc. share is respect for the transition that is accomplished when putting on sacred garments.

Yes, orale is niche. No apology for that other than ‚Äúcrosswordese.‚Äù But, an orale is a real thing, just as a judge‚Äôs robe, a barrister‚Äôs wig, a police officer‚Äôs badge, are real things, never to be donned without respect for that which is signified.

A very nice puzzle. The kind I like with multiple possible answers to the same clue. I was stuck on  spelling of the capital of Portugal until it suddenly became clear what the answer is to the final Across clue.

Loved this one. Surprised to learn how many people were unfamiliar with ZERO MOSTEL; in addition to "Tevye" he created the role of "Pseudolus" in "A Funny Thing Happened On The Way To The Forum"--two iconic musical theatre roles, both of which earned him Tony Awards. *And* he co-starred, with Gene Wilder, in one of the funniest movies ever made, Mel Brooks' The Producers. *And* he was black-listed thanks to the HUAC, and managed to come back strong, even starring in a Martin Ritt film about the blacklist, The Front.

And as Pinky once said to Brain:

"I think so Brain; but Zero Mostel times anything will still give you Zero Mostel."

Narf!

That was fast (for me) and fun except ORALE crossing with ITAL and KOLA. 

Now I'm hungry for Japanese. I would make miso, but I'm low on katsuobushi and out of kombu for the dashi. Time for a trip to H Mart!

Wow.  I feel like I made this harder than it should have been.  I should have gotten "whom" much more easily (after trying "thou" and "them" for far too long).   Had (unwarranted) trouble getting "ccs" in the lower left after trying "worn" for dad humor...   (obviously) tried "moo" and "baa" before leaving "maa" (owing to crosses) with a head scratch and a shrug.   I don't feel at all bad for not knowing (and struggling with) "Abelard" or "orale".    
   "Halo" is awesome and I liked "exes" too.  Nice theme.  I played some volleyball growing up in California.  Thanks Laura!
HI!   Can someone please share with me the origin of all these inside-joking emu references???

A lot of crosses I thought were unfair in this one:

IONE crossing ASTLEY (is it ionA or ionE?)
ORALE crossing KOLA (koNa is also coffee-related)
SOBA crossing ABALARD (is it sobA or sobE?) (or maybe it's Erdoc instead of Ordoc?)
PRATE crossing EREBUS (though nothing else made sense)

I couldn't figure out the correct combination of letters.

This was the hardest Wednesday I can remember. Typically the comments about difficulty on this forum reflect my own experience, and I must say that I'm surprised that some people found this one to be Tuesday-level. 

I had never heard of ORALE, and had probably heard of KOLA but had no idea what the third letter was; and for some reason I had never heard of the word PRATE. Is it common? And, of course, had never seen either ZERO MOSTEL or EREBUS. Luckily there are not many endings of PRA?? that give an English-sounding word, and an alphabet run finally gave me the ORALE/KOLA.

But for a while I thought that my 255-day streak would end because of a Wednesday!
Odd thing about WHOM: though correct, it feels almost pedantic to use it.

@Steve 

Since you're from England, I imagine you don't see the wordplay here.

In baseball, when a runner is on third base, he can score if he can make it home after a fly ball (a ball hit into the air) is caught.  (Note, he can only leave the base after the catch is made.)  A deep fly ball often accomplishes this, and is an out for the batter.  But unless it's the third out, and the inning is over, the runner at third can attempt to score.  

There are times when this one run is the margin of victory, so the action of the batter, even though he is out, is not viewed as a negative.  He has said to have hit a sacrifice fly, and it does not count against his batting average.

Although it's a little stretchy to say that when you SWAT a fly, you're sacrificing it, but we also use SWAT in reference to hitting a baseball far, so now you can see the wordplay there.

@Charlie The Google Ngram corpus doesn't bear this out. "She prattled" occurs about twice as often as "he prattled", overall. The difference has converged rather dramatically in American English recently (not in British English), but "she" has outweighed "he" continuously since the mid-nineteenth century. It's particularly noticeable in the English Fiction corpus: https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=he+prattled%2Cshe+prattled&year_start=1800&year_end=2022&case_insensitive=true&corpus=en-fiction&smoothing=3 But the proportion is actually reversed with regard to "he prated"/"she prated"---"he" being quite strongly favoured, albeit with pretty small numbers recently. (So it seems to be much less "equal opportunity" than my own recollection suggested.) https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=he+prated%2Cshe+prated&year_start=1800&year_end=2022&case_insensitive=true&corpus=en-fiction&smoothing=3 The evidence, from those corpora at least, is that both verbs are gendered, with "prattled" female and "prated" male.
